comments:
Keep getting the dump below when starting up the RCP M9.

!SESSION may 25, 2004 09:09:52.302 -------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=I200405211200
java.version=1.4.2_02
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=fi_FI
!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi touko 25, 2004 09:09:52.302
!MESSAGE Startup error
!STACK 1
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Bundle org.eclipse.update.configurator not
found.
    at
org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.loadBasicBundles(EclipseStarter.java:431)
    at
org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.startup(EclipseStarter.java:219)
    at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:125)
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
    at
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
    at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
    at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:185)
    at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:638)
    at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:622)

RCP is not something to run in itself. It is provided as a base for you to 
build your applications.

That said, you encovered here an inconsistency in what we ship in the RCP drop.
Indeed the the eclipse.properties file list, in the osgi.bundles property 
org.eclipse.update.configurator, a plugin which does not belong to the minimal 
set of RCP plugins.

To get you going I would recommand you to specify in the config.ini 
a new value for osgi.bundles. For example you say: 
  osgi.bundles=org.eclipse.core.runtime@2:start

For us, the fix will consists in specifying a different config.ini when 
building the rcp feature.
CC'ing Sonia to get her advise.

When fixing the config.ini, another message will come up:

java.lang.RuntimeException: No application id has been found.
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run
(PlatformActivator.java:294)
        ...

Does the RCP Runtime and SDK does NOT have a default app shipped ?

BTW: When unpacking RCP into a directory "C:\Folder With Blanks", the error 
message will be cut after the first blank. I only see:
  An error has occured. See the logfile
  C:\Folder

This is what I indicated in the first paragraph of comment #1.
RCP is *not* an application. It is a base to build against.

You can do the analogy with Java where if you run java.exe nothing happens.

Created an attachment (id=11210)
The config file for RCP.

Find in the attachement the config.ini file to provide in RCP.
Updated build to include this config.ini in RCP drops.

Pascal, cna you check out the "install Eclipse in a dir with spaces" usecase 
and ensure that this is sane?

Moving to platform since this requires a reorganisation of files in the
repository for the rcp and platform features.

Fixed for I200405281200 by doing the following:

1.  moved the "configuration" directory under org.eclipse.platform-
feature/rootfiles to configuration.files.
2.  updated build.properties in org.eclipse.platform-feature and 
org.eclipse.sdk-feature to copy configuration directory from new location.

The eclipse.buildId value in the config.ini for the rcp drops contained a hard-
coded value.  Replaced with @build@ for updating at buildtime.

traces.message: No application id has been found.
